Certainly! Here is a revised version of the non-deterministic matrix that could be used to model the situation of a person deciding whether or not to go to a party:

Example:

* $X = {0, 1, 2}$
* $Y = {1, 2}$
* $V = {\text{go}, \text{stay}}$
* $C = {\neg, \text{or}}$
* $arity(\neg) = 1$
* $arity(\text{or}) = 2$
* $\cdot(\neg, 0) = {1, 2}$
* $\cdot(\neg, 1) = {0, 2}$
* $\cdot(\neg, 2) = {0, 1}$
* $\cdot(\text{or}, 0, 0) = {0}$
* $\cdot(\text{or}, 0, 1) = {1}$
* $\cdot(\text{or}, 0, 2) = {2}$
* $\cdot(\text{or}, 1, 1) = {1}$
* $\cdot(\text{or}, 1, 2) = {1, 2}$
* $\cdot(\text{or}, 2, 2) = {2}$
* $\cdot(\text{or}, 1, 0) = {1, 2}$
* $\cdot(\text{or}, 2, 0) = {2}$
* $\cdot(\text{or}, 2, 1) = {1, 2}$

In this revised non-deterministic matrix, the truth-value 0 represents certainty that the proposition is false, the truth-value 1 represents a possibility that the proposition is true, and the truth-value 2 represents a possibility that the proposition is false.
